results.headline: Rooting for Lovable Loser in a Furry Purple Suit
results.summary_short: “The Paranoids” plays like a dawdling sitcom that strings together small incidents into not very much.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Paranoids

results.headline: Reimagining the Culprit in Versace’s Murder
results.summary_short: According to “Murder in Fashion,” the real culprit in the murder of Gianni Versace was the aesthetic tyranny of gay culture.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Murder in Fashion

results.headline: Portrait of a Gay Childless Couple
results.summary_short: In the breeding dramedy “Misconceptions,” a childless gay couple enters into a holy alliance with a fertile Christian wife.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Misconceptions

results.headline: Exploring the Mysteries of Other People’s Lives
results.summary_short: “The Girl on the Train” involves a quest that leads to a scapegoat and a scandal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl on the Train

results.headline: Desperate Father’s Plea to a Detached Scientist
results.summary_short: “Extraordinary Measures,” the first feature released by CBS Films, rises above some of its made-for-TV trappings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Extraordinary Measures

results.headline: The Great Evolutionist Bares His Own Soul
results.summary_short: The film “Creation” is an account of Darwin as a young man and a father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Creation

results.headline: Mining Frail Aspirations in Rural China
results.summary_short: The first feature from the young Chinese director Zhang Chi, “The Shaft” (“Dixia de Tiankong”) feels as though it were made by a very old soul.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Shaft

results.headline: Poet in Exile, Still Gripping His Memories
results.summary_short: “A Room and a Half” is a rich, heady fictionalized biography of the exiled Russian poet Joseph Brodsky.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Room and a Half

results.headline: A Late Bloomer, Still Reveling in the Spotlight
results.summary_short: “Pop Star on Ice” is one part hagiography and two parts psychotherapy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pop Star on Ice

results.headline: Marriage and Mores in Rain-Soaked Hanoi
results.summary_short: Bui Thac Chuyen’s moody, enigmatic film is a subtle, melancholy exploration of erotic angst and uncomfortable awakening.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adrift

results.headline: Watch Out for That Disembodied Head, Girls
results.summary_short: Delirious, deranged, gonzo or just gone, baby, gone — no single adjective or even a pileup does justice to “House.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hausu

results.headline: A Reckless Teenager, Seeking Solitude Yet Craving Connection
results.summary_short: The contradictions of adolescence create their own sadness in Andrea Arnold’s tough and brilliant second feature, “Fish Tank.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fish Tank

results.headline: International Espionage? Kids Are Much Harder
results.summary_short: “The Spy Next Door” is a good-humored flurry of blown stunts and botched lines.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Spy Next Door

results.headline: Four-Legged Survivors of Hurricane Katrina
results.summary_short: One from the heart, the documentary “Mine” relates yet one more wrenching, infuriating story about Hurricane Katrina.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mine

results.headline: In This World, It Pays to Be a Loner
results.summary_short: With “The Book of Eli,” Allen and Albert Hughes have created a plausible post-apocalyptic world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Book of Eli

results.headline: For Israelis Now, Echoes of Strife Then
results.summary_short: Personal reminiscence and Israeli history are woven into a dense, occasionally impenetrable cinematic poem in Amos Gitai’s film “Carmel.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carmel

results.headline: Side by Side, With the Guilty, After Courts Send Them Home
results.summary_short: “My Neighbor My Killer” examines the emotional and judicial convulsions of post-genocide Rwanda.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Neighbor, My Killer

results.headline: Love Story That Flits Across Time and Space
results.summary_short: “Pyaar Impossible,” the latest romantic comedy from the Hindi-film powerhouse Yash Raj Films, is sweet, and as formula goes, deftly done and satisfying.

results.headline: Futuristic World Where Vampires Rule
results.summary_short: Among the many pleasures of “Daybreakers” is its reminder that vampire movies can function as more than just metaphors for teenage celibacy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daybreakers

results.headline: He’s in Love; Excuse His French
results.summary_short: “Youth in Revolt” is a sweet and slight and often charming coming-of-age tale.
